item.title: Whiz Comics
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: Publication Dates: June 1950 – February 1959 Number of Issues Published: 81 (#50 – #130) Color: Colour Cover; Black & White Interior Dimensions: Originally Gravure Magazine Size (#50-70); Later Letterpress Standard Silver Age U.S. Size (#71-End) Paper Stock: Newsprint Interior Whiz Comics was a monthly ongoing comic book anthology series, published by Fawcett Comics from […]
item.content:encoded:
Publication Dates: June 1950 – February 1959
Number of Issues Published: 81 (#50 – #130)
Color: Colour Cover; Black & White Interior
Dimensions: Originally Gravure Magazine Size (#50-70); Later Letterpress Standard Silver Age U.S. Size (#71-End)
Paper Stock: Newsprint Interior

Whiz Comics was a monthly ongoing comic book anthology series, published by Fawcett Comics from 19401953, best known for introducing Captain Marvel.

Whiz contained the following features depicting adventures of various superhero characters:

– Captain Marvel
– Ibis the Invincible
– Spy Smasher
– Golden Arrow
– Dan Dare
– Lance O’Casey
– Scoop Smith

62,65,74,75,78-81

item.title: TV Tornado
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: Publisher: City Magazines Publication Dates: 1967 – 1968 Number of Issues Published: 88 (#1 – #88) Information thanks to the Grand Comics Database TV Tornado was a weekly comic published from 1967 to 1968 by City Magazines. Solo merged into it in September 1967. Eventually TV Tornado itself merged into TV21. Comic strips – American […]
item.content:encoded:
Publisher: City Magazines
Publication Dates: 1967 – 1968
Number of Issues Published: 88 (#1 – #88)

Information thanks to the Grand Comics Database

TV Tornado was a weekly comic published from 1967 to 1968 by City Magazines.

Solo merged into it in September 1967. Eventually TV Tornado itself merged into TV21.

Comic strips

– American “Flash Gordon” reprints
– American “The Green Hornet” reprints
– American “The Lone Ranger” reprints
– American “Magnus, Robot Fighter” reprints
– American “The Phantom” reprints
– The Saint”
– American “Tarzan” reprints
– Swami Riva
– Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea”

item.title: TV Century21
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: TV Century21 Publisher: City Magazines-Century 21 Publications Publication Dates: 23 January 1965 – December 1967 Number of Issues Published: 154 (#1 – #154) Color: Colour Dimensions: Tabloid Binding: Saddle-stitched Publishing Format: Was ongoing series Publication Type: magazine Information thanks to the Grand Comics Database TV Century 21, later renamed TV21 (from issue 155), TV21 and […]
item.content:encoded:
TV Century21

Publisher: City Magazines-Century 21 Publications
Publication Dates: 23 January 1965 – December 1967
Number of Issues Published: 154 (#1 – #154)
Color: Colour
Dimensions: Tabloid
Binding: Saddle-stitched
Publishing Format: Was ongoing series
Publication Type: magazine

Information thanks to the Grand Comics Database

TV Century 21, later renamed TV21 (from issue 155), TV21 and Tornado (from issue 192), TV21 and Joe 90 (from issue 243), TV21 (from issue 278) and TV21 and Valiant (from issue 347), was a weekly British children’s comic published by City Magazines during the latter half of the 1960s.

The comic dropped the “Century” from its title in January 1968, after 155 issues, and became known as TV21. The previous year, the character of the “indestructible” Captain Scarlet, the hero of Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons (1967 68), had made his first appearance. The backstory of the Mysterons, Scarlet’s Martian enemies, was being revealed in TV Tornado, another City Magazines publication. In September 1968, after 192 issues, TV21 merged with TV Tornado to form TV21 and Tornado.

Strips included:

– American “The Adventures of Tarzan” reprints
– Burke’s Law”
– Captain Scarlet”
– Clancy Clott: Magician’s Mate”
– The Daleks”
– Fireball XL5″
– Forward from the Back-Streets”
– I’ve Got a Sports-Mad Dad”
– The Kid King”
– Lady Penelope” (Frank Langford)
– Land of the Giants”
– My Favourite Martian”
– The Saint”
– American “Spider-Man” reprints
– Star Trek”
– Stingray”
– Supercar”
– Tarzan” (from TV Tornado)
– Thunderbirds” (Frank Bellamy)
– The Tuffs of Terror Island”

item.title: TV Action
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: Publication Dates: April 1, 1972 – August 25, 1973 Number of Issues Published: 74 (#59 – #132) Color: part colour, part monochromatic Dimensions: 12 1/2″ x 8 3/4″ Paper Stock: matt newspaper stock Binding: glue binding Publishing Format: Was ongoing series Publication Type: magazine Cover title is “TV Action + Countdown” for #59-100, just “TV […]
item.content:encoded:
Publication Dates: April 1, 1972 – August 25, 1973
Number of Issues Published: 74 (#59 – #132)
Color: part colour, part monochromatic
Dimensions: 12 1/2″ x 8 3/4″
Paper Stock: matt newspaper stock
Binding: glue binding
Publishing Format: Was ongoing series
Publication Type: magazine

Cover title is “TV Action + Countdown” for #59-100, just “TV Action” for #101-132.

Information thanks to the Grand Comics Database

Strips included:

“Alias Smith and Jones”
“Autocat and Motormouse”
“Cannon”
“Dad’s Army”
“Doctor Who”
“Droopy”
“Hawaii Five-O”
“Mission Impossible”
“The Protectors”
“Tightrope”

item.title: Top Spot
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: Publication Dates: 1958 – 1960 Number of Issues Published: 65 (#1 – #65) Publishing Format: Was ongoing Top Spot was a weekly comic aimed at older readers, 16-17 year old office boys and apprentices, published by the Amalgamated Press, later Fleetway, beginning on 25 October 1958. It contained adventure strips, including “Fabian of the Yard”, […]
item.content:encoded:
Publication Dates: 1958 – 1960
Number of Issues Published: 65 (#1 – #65)
Publishing Format: Was ongoing

Top Spot was a weekly comic aimed at older readers, 16-17 year old office boys and apprentices, published by the Amalgamated Press, later Fleetway, beginning on 25 October 1958. It contained adventure strips, including “Fabian of the Yard”, a few humour strips, text stories, pin-ups of sex symbols like Marilyn Monroe and Brigitte Bardot, and articles on music and sports. It was edited by Brian Woodford. It never quite recovered after a six-week strike in 1959, and it was merged into Film Fun on 16 January 1960.

1

Download
